Award.AwardTitle: Asymptotics in Integrable Systems, Random Matrices and Random Processes, and Universality
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports U.S. participation in the workshop "Asymptotics in Integrable Systems, Random Matrices and Random Processes, and Universality" held at the Centre de Recherches Mathematiques (CRM), Montreal, during June 7-11, 2015. In recent years there have been several important developments in the study of certain equations describing the motion of waves as well as of large time or large system-size randomly interacting systems (such as the spread of bacterial colonies or the interactions between many electrically charged particles). The mathematical methods underlying these developments have surprising commonalities. This workshop will feature presentations by over two dozen experts in these diverse fields to present their recent research results and discuss directions of future efforts. About 25 more participants are expected to be present, including many researchers in their early careers. The workshop aims to advance the field and also to help the young researchers to identify important and promising new research directions.

The topics of workshop include integrable systems, random matrices andrandom processes, and their possible novel applications. These three areas have benefited from each other over the last two decades. In recent years all of them have seen new significant developments. This workshop aims to foster the exchange of these new ideas and developments by bringing together experts in these three areas to discuss progress and challenges.

Workshop web site: www.crm.umontreal.ca/2015/Deift15/index_e.php

POR.DRECONTENT:
This projected supported one workshop and one summer school. The workshop was "Asymptotics in Integrable Systems, Random Matrices, Random Processes and Universality" held at Centre de Recherches Mathematiques (CRM), University of Montreal, Canada during June 7-11, 2015. The workshop was about the new developments in the field of integrable systems, random matrices, and random processes. These are areas of mathematics which are developing fast. The workshop supported the experts come and give talks on their recent research results. There were 25 research talks, each of which was one hour long. The workshop also supported the participation of the junior participants. There was a poster session for them. One of the leading experts held an hour-long session of Open Research Directions, discussing the outstanding questions in the field. Some of the talks, including the Open Research Directions, were published as papers in a journal. The reactions of the participants were extremely positive, with several comments about the uniformly high level of all contributions.

The "2016 Summer School on Random Matrices" was held at the University of Michigan during June 12-24, 2016. It was for graduate students and postdocs in mathematics, statistics, and engineering department to be able to learn new tools in the area of random matrix theory from a series of lectures by four leading experts outside their usual courses offered in their own institution. Among 100 applicants, 58 participants who have some backgrounds on random matrix theory. The summer was extremely successful with enthusiastic reactions from the participants. There were several requests from the students asking if the summer school would continue.
